body:
Do you use sql lite ?

On Fri, Jan 27, 2017 at 9:25 PM, Anand Nadar <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> My Superset version is 0.15. Tried both, pip and docker installs but in
> both cases the page takes minutes to load. Most often the request runs in
> to 50x errors. The logs don't seem to indicate anything either. #1867
> <https://github.com/airbnb/superset/issues/1867> somewhat indicates the
> same issue. Also this issue is generic across all pages
>
> Wondering if there is something in the configuration that can help fix
> this. My hardware is a m4xlarge EC2 instance so don't this is a hardware
> issue. Tried other web applications on the same machine and they seemed to
> work fine so this is not because of the network.
>
> —

Best regards,
Bogdan Kyryliuk.
The pip install, uses sqllite I guess while the docker one was tried using mysql. So the answer is I tried both and slowness was seen in both cases.

How to specify the order by on metrics (computed columns) ?
For ex. if i want to show only top rows after order by  "particular_metric asc". What should i do. It looks like superset/caravel always sort in "desc". How to change that ?. Theres no field for that.

Any help here would be tremendous. I've spent another four hours banging my head and no matter what I try, I still get this error message.

@jerryhall to me it looks like you have built a python without sqlite3 bindings, then sqlalchemy tries pysqlite2 but you don't have it either. So fix your python installation :)
@gamefundas What do the logs say? Are you proxying gunicorn? Have you tried investigating where is the time spent?

We do have http proxy set in the session but at the same time we have no_proxy variables set to prevent any local traffic to hit the proxy. Does gunicorn use the no_proxy variable? Else I will have to unset everything prior to starting the process.

@gamefundas I don't understand whay you said, i meant an http proxy like nginx in front of gunicorn. Anyway whatever you have configured just do a curl 127.0.0.1:8088 (or whatever address) from the machine superset is running and see how long it takes.
I have the same issue for a PostgreSQL db on `superset==0.15.4` .
@axitkhurana @Simeon-ayo I believe that @SalehHindi is going to add some tests to the branch and get it prepped for a merge request.

LGTM, please test on staging

rotating 45 degrees makes the chart a bit smaller since we have to increase the right margin to accommodate the last label. when i look at these side by side, i think 90 degree labels work much better. @elibrumbaugh do you have any thoughts on this? @mistercrunch @vera-liu which do you think works better? vs.

Thanks for sharing this with me @ascott! From a legibility perspective, I think 45° works better than 90° here. However, the shrinking of the graph is an issue. If I had to trade off I would keep the labels 45° and allow the graph to be pushed in. One way I've seen this solved (sort of) in the past is to truncate long labels from the middle or end that are rotated 45°. For example: 1985-01-01 00:00:00 is 1985...00:00. On hover the entire label could be shown. This could also be a toggle to turn them on and off.
Indeed, thanks @silashundt
one other alternative, 60 degree rotation. vs 45 degrees
LGTM

here is the solution for the same so use % double times in the end 

EX: LIKE 'BEN%%'

Sqlite3 isn't in the setup.py for superset because it should be part of the
python standard library. If you're on aws try an Ubuntu based Ami, or even
a python optimised docker container on ecs. They usually come with nice
well behaved python installations.

this is happening on /expore/table/{id} as well as on Table View slices where there are no group by clauses. 

https://github.com/ascott/superset/blob/master/superset/viz.py#L202
`self.datasource.query(**query_obj)` is returning a failed query with this error.

```
'(sqlite3.OperationalError) near "FROM": syntax error [SQL: u"SELECT\\nFROM 
birth_names\\nWHERE ds >= \'2017-01-23 21:45:44.000000\'\\n  AND ds <= \'2017-01-30 
21:45:44.000000\' LIMIT 50000\\nOFFSET 0"]'
```

the query it's trying to run is 
```
SELECT\nFROM birth_names\nWHERE ds >= '2017-01-23 21:45:44.000000'\n 
AND ds <= '2017-01-30 21:45:44.000000' LIMIT 50000\nOFFSET 0
```

when it should be 
```
SELECT *\nFROM birth_names\nWHERE ds >= '2017-01-23 21:45:44.000000'\n  
AND ds <= '2017-01-30 21:45:44.000000' LIMIT 50000\nOFFSET 0
```

this is as far as I've gotten with this one. @bkyryliuk @mistercrunch @vera-liu anyone have any ideas how to fix this? the backend is not my strong point.

looks like the since/until options are working correctly however when the since/until options are given a year input like `1965`, the query is run with the following where clause
`WHERE ds >= '1965-01-31 00:00:00.000000'`. seems like this should be `WHERE ds >= '1965-01-01 00:00:00.000000'`. seems like a small edge case to me since the full date can be entered into the since option as `1965-01-01`. going to unassign myself, if someone else wants to grab this one. feel free.

this is a bug and/or a ux decision made by the folks who made [React Select](http://jedwatson.github.io/react-select/). It looks like it's not editable, but it actually is once you start typing:
![explore-edit-dates](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/130878/22457854/ae9b38d2-e74e-11e6-9068-4572fda682d7.gif)

Another fact that should be kept in mind:

python-ldap is not available for python3.
LDAP-auth is the sole reason why we run superset in a python2.7 venv.

Confirming this issue for Firefox 45.4.0.
I'm using Vivaldi browser as a workaround; however, FF-support is crucial in my eyes...

@rumbin except you can upgrade :) https://github.com/pyldap/pyldap.
@rumbin  Everyone has his/her own priorities, if it's crucial then please go fix it :)
:+1: Is it even possible to have datasource with same name but different hosts on the same superset instance?

@mistercrunch @JohnOmernik 
Here is the DBAPI for PyDrill.  I'm need to package this as its own module, but this does work.  Simply install pydrill then copy the contents of this archive into `<python-path>/site-packages/pydrill/` directory.  My intent is to submit a PR for PyDrill to get the DBAPI incorporated into that module, but I have to write up unit tests and test it on all the various python versions so that might take a while. 

Once you have this, then install this: https://github.com/cgivre/sqlalchemy-drill/tree/pydrill using `python setup.py install -- force` and you'll be able to connect Superset and Drill. 

[dbapi.zip](https://github.com/airbnb/superset/files/742547/dbapi.zip)

With all that said, the dialect and the DBAPI do work and I've been able to successfully create some charts and graphs with them.  I haven't been able to get any of the timeseries visualizations to work, and I'm not quite sure why yet.  I've also been able to execute arbitrary SQL statements via SQL Lab but I do run into issues when I try to visualize these statements. 

The issue is that when SQLAlchemy generates the new table it does so as follows:
SELECT field1, field2
FROM 
(SELECT field1, field2 
FROM table 1
) AS table1___

When using Joins and subqueries, Drill requires all fields to have table names and thus it throws an error.  Also SQLAlchemy seems to generate queries that use column aliases in GROUP BY clauses which also causes problems with Drill. 

I'll go through all the visualizations and write up what works and what doesn't so that others can take a look as well.

The problem lies in myself. because I use cnpm instead of npm, making my node_modules folder containing soft links which caused `python setup.py install` dist assets folder in loop.

i thought we had fixed this issue so you could use a single `%` but i believe a work around is to use `%%` in your query.

does this work for you?
```sql
SELECT DISTINCT LOWER(QUERY), COUNT FROM pdns 
WHERE query LIKE ('%%ocsp%%') 
ORDER BY count 
DESC limit 15;
```
closing in favor of https://github.com/airbnb/superset/issues/2053
`%%` does indeed works perfectly. Thank you!

I see similar behavior with Superset running slow queries in an Oracle DB - the "Worker timeout" message in logs:

> 2/2/2017 8:55:32 AM[2017-02-02 08:55:32 +0200] [1] [CRITICAL] WORKER TIMEOUT (pid:119)
> 2/2/2017 8:55:33 AM[2017-02-02 08:55:33 +0200] [123] [INFO] Booting worker with pid: 123

 and 

> undefined 
> An unknown error occurred. (Status: 0) Maybe the request timed out?

 

message in the UI. Usually, the timeout occurs at ~30s but I saw rare cases when the timeouts occurs at ~50s. I tried everything I could, I changed to async workers with celery but I still get the timeouts. I also adjusted SUPERSET_WEBSERVER_TIMEOUT without any change in behavior.

I don't know where this timeout comes from, please advice.

Thank you,
Virgil
@sid88in any new news about  tutorial videos ??
@xrmx: can this be merged then ? do i need to contact someone else for getting this in ?

I finally figured out how to fix this issue, I'm not sure what `SUPERSET_WEBSERVER_TIMEOUT` does but it doesn't seem to change the actual worker timeout. However the `runserver` command has a `-t` flag that does control the timeout.

So something like this should set the timeout to 90 seconds:
`superset runserver -t 90`
